item.title: Linked: 10/10 Would Graphic Design Again
item.description:
Visit Link

In her latest piece for It’s Nice That, Elizabeth Goodspeed addresses the love-hate relationship graphic designers have with their own profession and how it’s one of the only few careers that people within it warn others — either ironically or seriously (or both) — to not get into for their own sanity. It’s not a perfect profession or industry and it has its challenges and frustrations but, y’all, we’ve got it good.

item.title: Noted: New Logo and Identity for Bidetlity by LIT
item.description:
“Ass You Were”

(Est. 2021) “Bidetlity is all about reimagining intimate hygiene and challenging outdated habits. The young Berlin-based team designs products that not only improve personal care but also support both physical and mental well-being. With a focus on sustainability and innovative self-care, Bidetlity aims to spark a change – paving the way for a more conscious and eco-friendly future.”

Design by
LIT (Berlin, Germany)

Related links
LIT project page

Relevant quote
Bidetlity is on a mission to educate people around the world about better alternatives. From bidet showers to toilet stools – they are all about the ass. The new brand we designed for them is all about breaking the taboo: The bold typography mimics the body’s natural curves, the colours create a warm atmosphere and easily applicable elements like the splash and butthole serve as the cherry on the top. If this doesn’t help to spread some love, what will?

Images (opinion after)

Opinion
The old logo was arguably fine, conveying a sense of simplicity and clinical cleanliness with its water droplet icon, light weight rounded sans serif, and overly polite color palette. The old packaging was also quite soft-spoken and literally trying not to call attention to itself as if it were ashamed of the category it lived in. Every element of this new iteration of the brand takes the complete opposite approach of what it had been doing before, starting with the logo. The minimalist water droplet icon has evolved into a plump buttock that will have you reaching for that 🍑 emoji and the wordmark abandons all politeness in favor of an in-your-face, heavily condensed serif. (Queens, used throughout the identity, looks like it was also used as the basis for the wordmark before being squeezed and rounded-cornered.) I'm not sure I can say I like either element based on their execution or even their aesthetic but the energy feels right as well as being fun, lively, and surprising… like a splash of fresh water up your butthole. The identity doesn't stop there and goes full in on some lowbrow humor, at first with some headline typography where the counterspaces of the letters are drawn to look like an anus and if they are not meant to be drawn like that then I apologize, dear reader, for having my mind in the gutter. When not anus-ed, the typography, using Graf Rounded, is just plain fun if, at times, exhausting to read. The icon is used as a pattern but when it flops unto the screen in some of the animations it starts to look a little more like a scrotum, which I guess needs a fine splash of water every now and then but is perhaps a little off-putting. The color palette is… interesting. I like the purple and mint pastels and the bright orange is a nice spark but the red-ish brown, well, we all know what it reminds us of. Aside from its possible interpretations, its darkness and saturation are at odds with the rest of the colors. The packaging looks pretty good and is a big improvement over the old one that looked more like a dental hygiene product. The tone of voice is unapologetic and doesn't pull any punches when it comes to mentioning butts, poop, and holes of different kinds, which I don't have a problem with but it perhaps lacks some cohesion in terms of headline structure and how flippant or aggressive or charming it wants to be. Overall, this is undoubtedly memorable and the brand embraces its market niche with humor and personality so that we may all benefit from a cleaner, fresher, and happier butthole — amidst the chaos of the world, this feels like an attainable, rewarding goal.

item.title: Reviewed: Friday Likes 532: From Violaine & Jérémy, Ariel Chiesa, and Estudio Paloma
item.description:
“From Violaine & Jérémy, Ariel Chiesa, and Estudio Paloma”

From ornate to minimalist to playful, a fun range of projects this week with work from Paris, Buenos Aires, and Lima.

VNV by Violaine & Jérémy

VNV Pâtisserie et Chocolaterie is a high-end, reservation-only, pastry and chocolate establishment founded by Valda Chang and Vincent Pelte that brings French traditions to Taiwan. The identity, designed by Paris, France-based Violaine & Jérémy, is as indulgently delicious as VNV’s creations, featuring twelve different hand-drawn “VV” monograms, an ornate custom alphabet to serve as moulds for chocolates, some detailed ornaments and borders, and a hero pineapple illustration, all in a luscious eighteenth-century French aesthetic. As usual, the attention to detail in the production of all the applications is stunning and the tight color palette of a muted mint, a dark green, a lime-ish green, and gold foil is a beautiful contrast to the dark brown inventions of the two founders. The supporting typography and fun copywriting is yet another tasty morsel in an already decadent project. See full project

Palito by Ariel Chiesa

Palito is a stylish, single toothpick costing $85. What do you get for that price? A toothpick that is “Crafted with neurotic precision and an unwavering commitment to detail” available in a range of premium woods… or well, not available as they are sold out. The identity, designed by Buenos Aires, Argentina-based Ariel Chiesa, gives the product a playful, charming, and rustic charm that helps offset the arguably ridiculous premise of the product and that, with the wrong design, could have easily been the douchiest, eye-rolling-est luxury product. In tandem with what is clearly the loveliest toothpick ever created, the packaging, typographic choices, paper selection, letterpress printing, and clear instructions on what to do and not to do with the toothpick really forces you to consider making an investment in this everyday object you can easily own for, like, 1 cent. See full project

Antonieta by Estudio Paloma

Antonieta is a catering bakery in Lima, Peru, offering cakes, cookies, and more, all with an extra colorful and vibrant layer of fondant-infused decorations. The identity, designed by local firm Estudio Paloma, takes an effortless cue from the tasty offerings with an exuberant script wordmark that looks like it was squeezed out of a piping bag with thick, gooey connections and supported by a system of colorful wavy graphics that are layered to yield some fun patterns, all in a vibrant palette of pink, yellow, green, and blue. Their ordering brochure is also worth a look as all of the wacky elements come together in a more formal way and some super fun cake, cookie, macaron, and cupcake diagrams help customers make the right choice, which, honestly, doesn’t look like there is a wrong choice to begin with. See full project

item.title: Linked: Lebron is Kenough
item.description:
Visit Link

Still running high from its Barbie movie success, Mattel has introduced the first “Kenbassador” — a collection that “celebrates influential Ken figures who are creating positive change and contributing to a better world for all” — and the first ever Ken of a professional athlete with a doll in “the likeness of basketball legend, author, activist and philanthropist” LeBron James. One inch taller than the standard Ken doll, the Lebron rendition is “clad in a custom varsity jacket over the LeBron James Family Foundation’s signature We Are Family t-shirt, Nike Terminator High sneakers, Beats headphones, sunglasses, a fanny pack, a watch and his perennial ‘I Promise’ band”. Flopping not included. (Sorry — signed an MJ, the GOAT, fan.)

item.title: Noted: New Logo and Identity for Taara by Nimble
item.description:
“Let There be Light”

(Est. 2017, dating back to 2013) “For the past eight years, Taara — a project incubated within X, Google’s Moonshot Factory — has been developing novel technology that uses beams of light to deliver high-speed, secure connectivity where fiber and wireless can’t – bringing abundant access to everyone, everywhere.”

Design by
Nimble (Atlanta, GA)

Related links
N/A

Relevant quote
In Sanskrit, Taara means "star" and symbolizes guidance—particularly for those who feel lost. The name reflects two defining qualities of stars: light and direction. Our wordmark’s lowercase ‘a’ letterforms are inspired by the Sanskrit script for the sound “Ta,” grounding our identity in this rich linguistic heritage.

Our wordmark also draws from late modernist typography, including the NASA worm logo (1975) and Wim Crouwel’s New Alphabet (1967). Both examples embody universality through reductive forms. Crouwel’s work, influenced by the constraints of early display technology, is especially relevant—echoing the way our terminals and chips use lenses and receivers to perceive the world.

Our icon directly reflects the meaning of Taara in Sanskrit: “star.” It represents both the sun and the role of stars in navigation, symbolizing guidance and connection.

Beyond its celestial meaning, the icon also evokes the light-based technology in our products—from lighthouses aiding communication to the lenses and apertures in our systems and the way photons appear when captured holographically.

The joined forms in our icon reflect how our technology enables point-to-point data transmission, bridging gaps and extending networks. In rare instances, the mark may be multiplied to symbolize amplification and abundance—reinforcing the scalability and power of our technology.

Images (opinion after)

Opinion
The old logo — if I have it correct and if it actually saw the light of day in any way (as there wasn't any kind of official, standalone, online presence for Taara before 2025) — was fine for the most part and if the star icon had been a little thinner to visually match the weight of the wordmark, it would have been solid. The new logo is literally and metaphorically rad(ical) — metaphorically in that I kind of love it and literally in that it takes a risk in cropping the “a”s in an unconventional way. The latter, though, is cleverly rationalized by the “a”s being inspired by the letter “त” — which is pronounced as “ta” — in Devanagari, which is the most common script used to write Sanskrit, which, as explained in the design quote above, is the language where the name of company comes from, meaning “star”. Complicated way of saying this is a conceptually- and visually-sound logo that eschews most tech brand trends and offers something refreshingly original. A double-star icon serves as a separate, supporting element and while it's a slick little drawing it doesn't quite make an impression… like, it's a nice detail but as far as operating as an identifier for the company, it may be too fragile. Still, it's a great sign-off in some of the applications like the business card or report. Speaking of which, the applications are all fairly straightforward, using Lateral as the main typeface in support of some strong photography and imagery that takes advantage of both the sci-fi-ish nature of the product and the landscapes of the remote locations where the product is the most beneficial, to yield an intriguing moody, techie, rural-y vibe. The copywriting is solid and I like how it's just very factual and clear where it could have easily taken a more savior-y tone. Overall, a smart-looking and smart-sounding identity that helps present an overly complex technology in a simple, efficient, and effective manner.

item.title: Reviewed: New Logo and Identity for Microsoft’s 50th Anniversary by Koto
item.description:
“Windows of Opportunity”

Founded in 1975 by Bill Gates and Paul Allen to develop program language-specific interpreters for microcomputers, Microsoft has since grown to become one of the top five information technology companies globally. In addition to being the world’s largest software maker, Microsoft also offers Internet, video gaming, communication, cloud computing services, and more. In celebrating their 50th anniversary this April, Microsoft aims to pay homage to “the dreamers, builders, and changemakers who shaped Microsoft’s journey while inspiring the next generation to push boundaries” with a logo, identity, and campaign designed by Koto.

Through a dynamic visual system, the campaign interweaves historical moments, pioneering products, and the human ingenuity that has driven Microsoft forward.

Artifacts—both past and present—form the foundation of this campaign’s visual system. From early versions of Windows and the rise of Xbox to today’s AI-powered Copilot, these elements tell the story of Microsoft’s impact across industries and cultures. Each artifact is carefully curated to reflect the diverse ways in which Microsoft technology has intersected with people’s lives over the last five decades.

The campaign’s 50th-anniversary logo—and main campaign artifact—reinforces this legacy. A nod to the original Windows logo—the first truly mainstream Microsoft brand—it embraces a retro feel while evolving through motion and 3D to remain firmly rooted in the present.

Koto provided text

The 50th anniversary logo takes the early Windows logos of the ’90s and Minecraft-ifies* it into a pixelated floating monolith, taking some liberties with the “window panes” to turn them into a “5” and a “0’. The Windows logo has never been a beacon of great design and I can’t say that this iteration changes that for me, but it does certainly evoke ’90s internet. Unfortunately, the color palette and treatment also evokes (major competitor) Google to a certain extent, to the point where if I saw this in a vacuum, I might think I had entered a time machine and believe it was Google’s 50th anniversary we were celebrating. All that said, it’s an interesting take, and the motion treatment is rather mesmerizing.

* A reminder that Minecraft is part of the Microsoft world as both Mojang (the studio that created it) and the Minecraft intellectual property were purchased by Microsoft for US$2.5 billion in 2014.

Microsoft’s identity for this milestone event follows three key compositional structures: Worlds, Iconic Moments, and Then & Now. These layouts flex between people-centric and product-centric executions, ensuring that Microsoft’s past, present, and future feel seamlessly interconnected.

Worlds place people and products within vivid and expressive capturing the tools and ideas that have transformed lives.

Iconic Moments revisit historical breakthroughs, showcasing Microsoft’s role in shaping technology and culture.

Then & Now juxtaposes innovations across decades, illustrating Microsoft’s relentless spirit of reinvention.

Koto provided text

The broad assortment of “artifacts” here, particularly when put into motion together in their amorphous “worlds,” evoke a sense of randomized y2k chaos that seems right for the melding of past-present-future they’re going for. Given that Microsoft unwittingly helped forge the ’90s and 2000s aesthetic that has since come back to haunt us all with a drop shadowed, chrome, rainbow vengeance, it seems only natural that said aesthetic should play such an integral role in a celebration of the company’s past. Kudos to Koto here for capitalizing on such a unique opportunity and not cowing to corporate blandness— I don’t think we’ve seen anything this edgy from Microsoft since its short-lived but absolutely METAL logo from 1980.

I will say that the font — Segoe Sans, aka Microsoft’s brand font since 2012 and the typeface that its current logo is set in — does not quite stand up to the rest of the identity elements. I understand the need to have some continuity with the overall brand, but it feels soft and out of place here, despite being rationalized in the press release as “reflecting clarity and momentum.” It would have been great to see them go with something bolder and fresher that could better hold its own within the system and use Segoe as a supporting typeface instead.

In an era where memes featuring 2000s Windows pop-ups have become internet cultural currency, capitalizing on classic Microsoft interfaces as a key graphic theme is another so-obvious-it’s-brilliant move by Koto— one that could only truly work, authentically, for this particular brand in this particular moment.

The elements come together in a handful of vague applications that successfully evoke a sense of intense nostalgia colored through a distinctly modern lens, and although it’s a feast for the eyes, it was at this point where I found myself asking… who exactly is all this for? Branding is typically so focused on a specific target audience with a particular desired end goal for said audience, but in this case, neither is especially clear, and Koto’s presentation gives barely any insight into how all this might get applied. Presumably it’s meant to resonate with some die-hard Microsoft users who might be excited about a new Teams background, and more likely, the company’s investors, partners, and 200k+ employees, but it’s not entirely clear how that gap is being bridged.

Given a dearth of application examples, I did some light sleuthing on the interwebs to find out how the theoretical would translate to the actual, unavoidably getting a little bit watered down in the process. I will say that, with the exception of the use of Segoe Serif on the Microsoft blog (which feels even worse than just using the sans), this seems to be a rare scenario in which the execution of the identity by the client appears to be decently faithful to the original spirit (if not the high level of polish) of the studio’s design.

At the end of the day, as I am a) not a Microsoft employee and b) a staunch despiser of every Microsoft product I have ever interacted with, this identity was not meant for me, and there are parts of it I find vaguely baffling that perhaps a true Microsoft stan would better appreciate. That said, it feels at once incredibly unexpected and entirely fitting for the company, and offers a visual feast that anyone on the internet, particularly a child of the ’90s such as myself, can appreciate (while simultaneously cringing at).

item.title: Announced: IH/IF/IP/2025: Summary, Sights, and Sample Content
item.description:
“An Illustrated Overview of the 2-Day Event”

Here is the breakdown of the 16 sessions of the inaugural In-house In-focus In-person that took place this past March 27 – 28 in Dallas, TX, and which was awesome. (If you are looking at this in an RSS reader head on over to the real thing, too much heavy formatting). This is a very long post with a photo of each speaker, a highlight of their presentation, and some sample slides from their deck, so give it a good time to load. A few other things worth bullet-pointing:

  • Unlike the Brand New Conference, videos can not be purchased so if you like what you see below, consider registering for the 2026 edition!
  • A lot more photos from the event have been posted in this Flickr album.
  • Samples of the program, tote bag, and t-shirt are available for purchase.
  • Registration is now open for In-house In-focus In-person In 2026 in Chicago, IL, on March 19 – 20 at Harris Theater at Millennium Park.

All event photos by Sofia Negron. (On the grid images below you can click to open a bigger version.)
